name: Kepler-129
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-129 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-129 is a star with 2.119999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.64 times its radius. It is located 1349.24 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-129 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-129 b

Kepler-129 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 15.79 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-129.

The mass of Kepler-129 b is 7.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-129 b is 2.37 that of Earth. At 7.59 Earth masses, Kepler-129 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-129 c

Kepler-129 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.39 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 82.20 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-129.

The mass of Kepler-129 c is 9.05 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-129 c is 2.55 that of Earth. At 9.05 Earth masses, Kepler-129 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-129, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
